body:
r? @nikomatsakis

(rust_highfive has picked a reviewer for you, use r? to override)

cc @rust-lang/compiler, there's some pretty significant trans changes here!
cc @vadimcn, lots of windows changes
cc @brson, build system changes! (and llvm changes)
Oh and I think it's important to wait for travis before r+'ing this b/c that make sure that we're still compatible with LLVM 3.7 (which I believe is important for now)
Travis failed compiling RustWrapper.cpp on LLVM_VERSION_MINOR < 8 paths.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30457) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

Nice work, @alexcrichton!

After the first pass this looks fine to me. 
I'll try to find some time to build this branch and play with it.  I might have more insights then.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30352) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
Impressive.

Ok, I've now pushed an updated version which handles caching better on MSVC. The caching for GNU/landingpad exceptions should be the same as it was before, and the [IR for the snippet above](https://gist.github.com/alexcrichton/555a0292525c1131d181) in MSVC shows the caching being used as well.

Currently the caching isn't _as_ aggressively used on MSVC as it is on GNU b/c on MSVC you can't jump to the middle of a set of cleanup scopes, only the front. Perhaps that only matters for corner cases though?
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30481) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

@nikomatsakis, @nagisa 

Updated with comments addressed hopefully!

> What makes one version more aggressive than the other?

This has to do with [this comment](https://github.com/alexcrichton/rust/blob/9cf0e0673c41b3d6b3a619e56bbe0ed323ddc122/src/librustc_trans/trans/cleanup.rs#L862-L879). The gist of it is that if there are multiple entries in `popped_scopes` when generating landing pads, only the _last_ one will be used as a "cached early exit" for MSVC. With GNU exceptions all the intermediate ones will be used as well. This is because with GNU exceptions we can jump to any other basic block and keep going, but with MSVC exceptions we can't do that because each basic block can be a member of only one "funclet", so we have to be able to statically know which basic blocks are part of which cleanup pad chain.

Does that make sense? I fear that this is a little obscure and I have perhaps not commented enough, so please don't hesitate to ask for clarification!

On Mon, Jan 11, 2016 at 09:54:44PM -0800, Alex Crichton wrote:

> Does that make sense? I fear that this is a little obscure and I have perhaps not commented enough, so please don't hesitate to ask for clarification!

Yes, but a quick point of clarification. Earlier you hinted that there is in fact a way to chain funclets by "throwing" to another funclet or something like that
(can't be bothered to look up the exact terms). This is being deferred for future work, right? (Sorry, PR is out of cache just now)

Ah no worries, having funclets "throws to other funclets" was actually implemented, and it looks like this: https://github.com/alexcrichton/rust/blob/9cf0e0673c41b3d6b3a619e56bbe0ed323ddc122/src/librustc_trans/trans/cleanup.rs#L780-L803

So I was looking at the LLVM history today and there's been quite a number of WinEH commits since the LLVM revision I pinned this to. Many of them were specifically around verification of funclets, so I decided to update LLVM and see what happened. That update is not currently part of this PR, and I don't _think_ that it will be necessary, but I learned something interesting I wanted to share!

So far I ended up [just running into an LLVM bug](https://llvm.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=26147) during optimizing libstd, but it brought up a [very interesting comment](https://llvm.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=26147#c1). The gist of it (as I understand) is that a `call` instruction in a funclet which leads to unwinding is considered undefined behavior. Note that we have many `call` instructions in funclets (e.g. calling drop glue, and notably not `invoke`s), and destructors are definitely allowed to panic (although seriously advised against). We're safe from undefined behavior, however, because we can only ever be part of a funclet via a panic, and then a subsequent panic will abort the entire process.

What this means, I believe, is that on MSVC it will be required for memory safety to have double panics lead to aborts for now. We can fix this by having funclets use `invoke` instead of `call` and properly handling a panicking destructor in a panicking destructor, but it's largely just something to keep in mind.

On Thu, Jan 14, 2016 at 10:08:12PM -0800, Alex Crichton wrote:

> What this means, I believe, is that on MSVC it will be required for memory safety to have double panics lead to aborts for now. We can fix this by having funclets use `invoke` instead of `call` and properly handling a panicking destructor in a panicking destructor, but it's largely just something to keep in mind.

Interesting. I think I've come to the conclusion that I would want
dtors to be "noexcept" (i.e., if unwinding reaches the dtor, it
aborts) as well, at least for consistency. I wonder if we can make
that change.

> I wonder if we can make that change.

Not sure if that’s a valid way forward. Panicking (and thus unwinding from) in destructors is valid, as long as the panicking destructor is only called during regular cleanups and not unwind-cleanups.

We could make an RFC and a bunch of lints to forbid unwinding from destructors though, but I’m not sure it is considerable at all as pre-2.0 material.

Ok, I've pushed the upgrade to LLVM which actually now puts us on the `release_38` branch of LLVM. This should mean it'll be pretty easy for us to track changes there as 3.8 is release in the (hopefully) near future.

I've implemented [the recommended workaround](https://llvm.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=26147#c3) for the LLVM bug for now, which is to annotate all `call` instructions with `nounwind` if they happen in a cleanup pad. Note that this is indeed true at runtime because a second panic rooted in a cleanup pad is a double-panic which will abort the process.
The specific change [is here as well](https://github.com/alexcrichton/rust/blob/llvmup/src/librustc_trans/trans/build.rs#L931-L952)

Turns out we've got some MIR tests which are exercising unwinding functionality, but as these changes aren't ported over to MIR just yet I'm going to disable those tests on MSVC and I've opened up https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/30941 to track the implementation.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30890) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30931) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

@nagisa traditionally we have said that the semantics of panics in a dtor
are an area we reserve the right to change (eg in the language semver rfc),
but it may be that we would break too much working code to actually change
things there. This is why I said "I wonder if we can make the change...."
On Jan 15, 2016 6:55 AM, "Simonas Kazlauskas" notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I wonder if we can make that change.
> 
> Not sure if that’s a valid way forward. Panicking (and thus unwinding
> from) in destructors is valid, as long as the destructor is only called
> during regular cleanups and not unwind-cleanups.
> 
> We could make an RFC and a bunch of lints to forbid unwinding from
> destructors though, but I’m not sure it is considerable at all as pre-2.0
> material.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/30448#issuecomment-171943063.
I’ve submitted a counter-PR against alexcrichton:llvmup with a basic MIR implementation of this thing.

rebased and chatted on IRC with @nagisa about the MIR implementation, it looks like it's missing the "all call instructions must be annotated with the funclet they're in" temporarily, so I'm gonna hold off on merging just yet

I discovered additional difficulties implementing this in MIR and will land MIR implementation independently once this PR lands.

I overall like the new instructions, and I find the changes proposed by this PR okay. I dislike us maintaining so much extra function-wide state in regards to the additional EH implementation, but I don’t immediately see any obvious way around it.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30845) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

> Ok, I've pushed the upgrade to LLVM which actually now puts us on the release_38 branch of LLVM. This should mean it'll be pretty easy for us to track changes there as 3.8 is release in the (hopefully) near future.

I mentioned this on IRC, but if the going gets rough for the unwinding parts of this PR, could the LLVM upgrade aspect be split out? I'm attempting to track some of the [changes for llvm-avr](https://github.com/avr-rust/rust/issues/14) which is also tracking LLVM HEAD.

I moved us further along the LLVM 3.8 release branch which includes a fix for the issue I found above, which means that there's no longer any need to tag `call` instructions in a landing pad as `nounwind` (although we can probably continue to do this anyway due to our double-panic-is-abort situation.

OK, so, I read through this branch again. I also talked some to @alexcrichton offline. Basically, I think we can do better with the re-use here. In particular, if you have four nested scopes, like:

```
SCOPE_A
SCOPE_B
SCOPE_C
SCOPE_D
```

then what I expect is that we should generate one LLVM "funclet" per scope, and use the `cleanupret` instruction to chain between them. What this branch actually does is to (sometimes) put multiple scopes in the funclets. What I'd prefer to see would thus look like:

```
UNWIND_A: 
    token_a = cleanuppad();
    cleanupret(token_a, caller);

UNWIND_B:
    token_b = cleanuppad();
    cleanupret(token_b, UNWIND_A);

UNWIND_C:
    token_c = cleanuppad();
    cleanupret(token_c, UNWIND_B)

UNWIND_D:
    token_d = cleanuppad
    cleanupret(token_d, UNWIND_C);
```

In terms of MIR, it seems like we should basically adopt this "funclet" model -- marking basic blocks as either normal, or tagging them as "unwind" (and carrying along the "funclet" code, rather than making a fake value to represent it). This is trivially translatable to MSVC and trivially erasable to GNU (with branches).
(That said, I'd be happy to leave that as a FIXME)

@nikomatsakis ok I think I've implemented what we talked about. I added a few helper functions to `cleanup.rs` and I think it's a little cleaner how the changes were applied (and easier to follow the control flow). It's at least a little clearer to me now that the logic is basically the same and as much caching happens afterwards as it does before.

The IR [for a simple function](https://gist.github.com/alexcrichton/15c06b98e122a12d707e) is [pretty awful](https://gist.github.com/alexcrichton/82dad941d9b6710b9753) as you can see [cleanuppads are _immediately_ followed by cleanupret](https://gist.github.com/alexcrichton/82dad941d9b6710b9753#file-foo-ll-L52-L53), as well as tons of branching via `cleanupret`. That being said, however, it looks like it's legal from LLVM's point of view and it also does [quite a good job optimizing it](https://gist.github.com/alexcrichton/8bc67b8215a5caad6435) into basically exactly what one might expect.
@alexcrichton indeed, it looks nicer now. I am pleased. Thanks for putting in the effort.
@bors r+

Ugh, I forgot about this. We're going to need to upgrade the gcc/g++ on the windows bots as apparently 4.9.3 doesn't have `std::thread` in the C++ standard library which LLVM now requires. I'll probably just pick the newest toolchain (which I think is 5.3.0) from the mingw-w64 project.

cc @vadimcn, @brson, may mean some upcoming distribution issues!
As @vadimcn pointed out on IRC https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/28260 may throw a wrench in the works, but who knows! (I certainly don't...)

Ok, I've done a few things:
1. I've created two temporary commits in our LLVM branch
   - https://github.com/rust-lang/llvm/commit/ae6a38329e0b40ed5a7bd1d31ffe0ba48ead1cc7 is a cherry-pick of https://github.com/llvm-mirror/llvm/commit/707c12c224206155ede6c172df8d264d43ddd4c1 which just isn't in the `release_38` branch at this time.
   - https://github.com/rust-lang/llvm/commit/664319f7cca6374c320adf0ebe38305bca50ac68 is my attempt to get LLVM to compile on mingw-w64 by just not compiling any part of LLVM that needs `std::thread`. It looks like all portions aren't used by Rust itself at least. Note that this is similar to https://github.com/rust-lang/llvm/commit/0be2a329e6dff0b6996ab256e0c1d39da975a519 in that it's not our first "let's make LLVM compile everywhere we need" patch.
2. As we're not using `std::thread`, I'm not upgrading gcc on the bots

@bors: r+ 7f0d1f7fdfe65c1aa85a7bd7c81f2cf2617e0e02

er

@bors: r=nikomatsakis 7f0d1f7fdfe65c1aa85a7bd7c81f2cf2617e0e02

> As we're not using std::thread, ...

We aren't?  I thought it was needed for parallel codegen?
